questions.text: The police hands over the body of a person who died due to hanging to you for an autopsy. Which of the following incisions is preferred in this case?
questions.solution:
The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression (as in hanging) is the modified Y-shaped incision.

In strangulation, hanging, and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, a modified Y-shaped incision is to be preferred. This incision is used because the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised to give a wide approach to the neck structures.

Given below are types of incisions done for an autopsy:

Y-Shaped Incision: Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side. It runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum in the midline. It then runs downwards as in an I-shaped incision to the symphysis pubis. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy.

Modified Y-shaped incision: An incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from the suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. Indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck. 

I-Shaped Incision: Extends from symphysis mentii to symphysis pubis taking curve towards left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice. It is simple and convenient.

Elongated X-shaped Incision: This is a special incision used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries, which are usually missed where superficial imprints are faint, particularly when present on skin not overlying bone. This is helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death and should be practiced in cases of custodial death.

Inverted Y-shaped incision is used in infants.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch and then run downwards as in the “I” shaped incision.  Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent inhaled anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The most potent inhaled anesthetic among the given options is halothane, with a minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of 0.75%.

The least potent inhaled anesthetic is nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%.

Note: Methoxyflurane has a MAC of 0.16%, making it more potent than halothane. However, it is obsolete now. The most potent agent overall is methoxyflurane and the most potent agent in clinical use is halothane.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

questions.text: Sexual identity does not depend on which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Sexual identity does not depend on upbringing. Sexual identity is the pattern of a person’s biological sexual characteristics.

It depends on the following:

  • Chromosomes
  • External and internal genitalia
  • Hormonal composition
  • Gonads
  • Secondary sex characteristics

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: A G2P1 GDM patient was admitted in labor. During labor, a diagnosis of shoulder dystocia has been made. The obstetrician performed the following maneuver. This maneuver is named as _______
questions.solution:
The manoeuvre shown above is McRoberts manoeuvre.

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • This is the single most effective intervention and should be the first maneuver to be performed in shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this maneuver.

questions.text: A patient presented with vomiting to medicine OPD. He has a history of eating fried rice. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Food poisoning after eating fried rice is due to Bacillus cereus.

Food poisoning caused by B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8-16 hours 1-5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1-6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8-16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic E.coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E.coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient is febrile, scrotal erythema and on lifting the testis the pain is relieved. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with positive Prehn's sign is suggestive of acute Epididymo-orchitis. 

A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be testicular torsion.

Epididymo-orchitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the epididymitis and testis. The infection reaches the epididymitis from a primary infection of the urethra, seminal vesicles, or prostate. In young men, it is sexually acquired while in older men it is secondary to a urinary tract infection. It can occur post catheterization or instrumentation as well. 

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from a urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Clinical features include pain and redness in the scrotum, fever, and tenderness of the scrotum.

Initial investigations include urine specimen for culture, Nucleic acid amplification testing(NAAT), and a urethral swab to check for signs of infection. An ultrasound of the epididymis can show inflammation and abscess formation if any. 

Treatment is by antibiotics and scrotal support.

Note: 

A common differential is a testicular torsion which needs urgent surgical exploration. A Prehn's sign is used to differentiate torsion from epididymo-orchitis.

Chronic tuberculous epididymo-orchitis presents as a painless swelling of the scrotum with a firm enlarged epididymis, beading of the vas deferens, and a normal testis on palpation.Beading of the vas deferens is due to subepithelial tubercle formation and is specific to genital tuberculosis.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and KF rings are diagnostic in symptomatic cases of Wilson's disease.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

Option B: The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Option C: ATP7B enzyme assays have shown promise in early studies as a neonatal screening test for Wilson's disease. However, it is not yet part of routine clinical practice.

Option D: Karyotyping is done for every asymptomatic 1st and 2nd degree relative of a patient with Wilson’s disease. This helps differentiate the carriers (heterozygous) from the patients (homozygous) and can lead to early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist against the following receptor _______
questions.solution: Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist acting against the CCR5 receptor. It binds to host cell CCR-5 receptor and prevents binding of viral gp-120 to host cells. It is indicated in patients with evidence of infection with predominantly CCR-5 tropic virus.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the mandibular left posterior region since 2 months. The swelling was initially small and quickly increased in size. Incisional biopsy was done, and histopathological analysis of the hematoxylin/eosin-stained material showed sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stain positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The tumour is most likely an embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma: Malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation
  • Three subtypes: alveolar (20%), embryonal (60%), and pleomorphic (20%).
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (alveolar and embryonal): Most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood and adolescence.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.
  • The pediatric forms often arise in the sinuses, head and neck, and genitourinary tract.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma frequently contains fusions of the FOXO1 gene to either the PAX3 or the PAX7 gene, rearrangements marked by the presence of (2;13) or(1;13) translocations, respectively.
  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Rhabdomyoblasts with visible cross-striations may be present.
  • Sarcoma botryoids: variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina with cambium layer.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - Large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells
  • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin
  • The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumor penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.

Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma (in general):

TNM staging Treatment
T1a Simple cholecystectomy
T1b, T2, T3 Radical cholecystectomy
T4 Unresectable, chemotherapy and palliative nonsurgical therapy are provided
N1 Regional lymphadenectomy
N2 Radical cholecystectomy plus hepatopancreatic duodenectomy


If the carcinoma gall bladder was found incidentally after cholecystectomy:

  • Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, standard cholecystectomy would suffice
  • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomy should be performed

If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer recommended.

Chemotherapy is not required in early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role.

Related Pearl: TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma

TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) guidelines, 8th edition:

TX: Main tumor cannot be assessed due to lack of information

T0: No sign of a primary tumor

Tis: Cancer is only in the epithelium (the inner layer of the gallbladder) and has not grown into deeper layers of the gallbladder.

T1: Tumor invades the lamina propria or the muscle layer (muscularis). 

  T1a:  Tumor invades the lamina propria

  T1b: Tumor invades the muscular layer

T2a: Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the peritoneum (the lining of the abdominal cavity). 

T2b: Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the liver, but has not invaded the liver.

T3: Tumor invades the serosa and/or it has grown directly into the liver and/or one nearby structure like the stomach, duodenum, colon, pancreas, or bile ducts outside the liver.

T4: Tumor invades the main blood vessels leading into the liver (portal vein or hepatic artery) or it has grown into 2 or more structures outside the liver.

 

NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed due to lack of information.

N0: Not spread to nearby lymph nodes 

N1: Spread to < 3 nearby lymph nodes

N2: Spread to >4 nearby lymph nodes 

 

M0: Not spread to distant sites 

M1: Tumor spread to distant sites such as the liver, peritoneum (the lining of the abdomen [belly]), or the lungs

 

AJCC Stage Stage grouping
0 TisN0M0
I T1N0M0
IIA T2aN0M0
IIB T2bN0M0
IIIA T3N0M0
IIIB T1-3N1M0
IVA T4N0 or N1M0
IVB Any TN2M0 or Any TAny NM1

questions.text: Pap smear is ________
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test. In case of positive test further investigations should be done.

Pap Smear Schedule

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

Ayres spatula:

  • One end is blunt and the other end is bifid.
  • Blunt end is used to take samples for vaginal cytology.
  • Bifid end is used to take Pap smear

Endocervical brush:

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who is a football player comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman Miller sign or Antral sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumor grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in glomus tumor, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - Antral sign or Holman Miller sign

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to the OG clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for 2 days at 12 weeks of gestation.  She also complains of excessive vomiting for one week. USG was done and it is given below.  What is the probable diagnosis____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of complete mole.  The USG image shows the characteristic “snowstorm” appearance seen in complete mole. Notably, a fetus and amnionic sac are absent. 

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception (IUD contraindicated)
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation, weekly until undetectable, then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer.

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Thyroid pulmonary metastases (chest radiograph)

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ovarian follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding.

 Ovarian follicular cysts are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage, or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, ulcer, or cervical carcinoma.
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected stable angina, which of the following findings are likely to be present?

choices.text: CK-MB is elevated ; Troponin T is normal
Troponin I is elevated ; Myoglobin is normal
Myoglobin is elevated ; CK-MB is normal
Troponin I is normal ; CK-MB is normal

questions.solution:
The levels of cardiac markers remain unchanged in stable and unstable angina as there is no necrosis of cardiac myocytes.

The clinical presentations of ischemic heart disease can be broadly classified into: 

  • Chronic coronary syndrome (CCS) - this includes
    • Stable angina - this is an episodic angina that occurs with predictable severity, frequency, and threshold of precipitation by stressors, and is relieved by rest and nitrates  
  • Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) - this includes
    • Unstable angina - this is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers
    • Myocardial infarction - it is the necrosis and death of a portion of the myocardium due to prolonged ischemia. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in this condition

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV seropositive male presents with raised violaceous plaques over the distal portion of the lower limbs. Biopsy shows a lesion composed of proliferating spindle cells along with small vessels and spaces containing red cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent and has the following three clinical stages:

  • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
  • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
  • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound healing procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The principal behind the wound healing procedure, as shown above, is negative pressure wound therapy.

Applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds and ulcers.

The negative pressure may act by decreasing oedema, by removing interstitial fluid and by increasing blood flow. As a result, bacterial counts decrease and cell proliferation increases, thereby creating a suitable bed for graft or flap cover.

questions.text: Which of the following items are disposed of in the yellow bag?
questions.solution:
Blood bags are disposed of in the yellow bag.

Gloves are disposed of in the red bag.

Sharps are disposed of in the white container.

Urine bags are disposed of in the red bag.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

The changes as per the new Biomedical waste management (amendment) rules, 2018 have been included in the above table and highlighted in green.

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of above facilities, shredding
or mutilation or combination of
sterilization and shredding. 

Microbiology, Biotechnology, Clinical Laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, Laboratory
cultures, stocks or
specimens of microorganisms,
live or
attenuated vaccines,
human and animal cell
cultures used in
research, industrial
laboratories, production
of biological, residual
toxins, dishes and
devices used for
cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/ plasma pyrolysis/ Disposal in a  secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production
and used or discarded
disinfectants.

 Disposed of by incineration or Plasma
Pyrolysis or Encapsulation in
hazardous waste treatment, storage and
disposal facility.

Chemical Liquid
Waste :
Liquid waste generated
due to use of chemicals
in production of
biological and used or
discarded disinfectants,
Silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded Formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body
fluids, liquid from
laboratories and floor
washings, cleaning,
house-keeping and
disinfecting activities
etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before
mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable Contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes(without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vaccutainers with needles cut and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by -  Shredding/mutilation

And later -  Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/Road making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/Mutilation/
Encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/Sanitary landfill/Waste sharps

 

 

  Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic Body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves is a pure sensory nerve?
questions.solution:
The olfactory nerve is a pure sensory nerve. It carries no motor fibers.

  • Olfactory: Sensory
  • Optic: Sensory
  • Oculomotor: Motor
  • Trochlear: Motor
  • Trigeminal: Both 
  • Abducent: Motor
  • Facial: Both
  • Vestibulocochlear: Sensory
  • Glossopharyngeal: Both
  • Vagus: Both
  • Accessory: Motor
  • Hypoglossal: Motor

"Both" stands for a mixed nerve (both motor and sensory).

Mnemonic: Some Say Marry Money But My Brother Says Big Brain Matters More.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with features of tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the report of the thyroid function test in Graves' disease?

choices.text: Radioactive Iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
In Graves' disease, the level of serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high and serum T3 is high. 

Graves disease is caused by autoantibodies that bind to the thyrotropin receptor (TSHR-Ab), stimulating the growth of the thyroid and overproduction of thyroid hormone(T4 and T3). These hormones then cause negative feedback to the anterior pituitary and thus, decrease TSH levels.

And in patients with thyrotoxicosis including Graves', the RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal.

The evaluation of thyrotoxicosis is given in the flowchart below:

Related Pearl: Radioactive iodine uptake scan

Hyperthyroidism with high/ normal uptake Hyperthyroidism with low uptake
Graves’ disease Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
Toxic MNG Thyrotoxicosis factitia
Toxic adenoma Viral
TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
HCG induced thyrotoxicosis Radiation thyroiditis, Struma ovarii

questions.text: The skin condition shown in the image below is seen in ____.
questions.solution:
• The image represents fish-like scales on the skin characteristically seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (Icthyos = Fish).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is a skin condition that happens when the skin does not shed the dead skin cells. This leads to a dry, dead skin cells that accumulate in small patches on the surface of the skin, especially on the arms and legs.
  • It is also called the "fish scale disease" due to the dead skin that accumulates in the same pattern to a fish’s scales.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

Its is a fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in Pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in Ichthyosis Vulgaris (Ichthyos = Fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery/mica-like scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Yellow/Greasy scale

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scale

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis Versicolor

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-electrical cold-chain equipment?
questions.solution:
Cold boxes, vaccine carriers, and ice packs are some of the non-electrical components of the cold-chain system.

  • Cold boxes are insulated containers used for transportation and temporary storage of vaccines and ice packs.
  • Vaccine carriers are usually not used for storage of vaccines but for their transportation.
  • Ice packs generally have two holes in them for placing vaccines. They are filled with water.

Cold chain equipment : 

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator

Transportation : 

  • Refrigerator vaccine van
  • Insulated vaccine van
  • Cold box 
  • Vaccine carrier

questions.text: A 30-day-old infant is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has a large and hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the CXR obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Severe pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. 

CXR features in ARDS:

  • Early findings include normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), which are often bilateral and which obscure the pulmonary vascular markings.
  • Later, these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse.

Prolonged bed rest increases the risk of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. However, the CXR shows diffuse alveolar opacities making the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia usually appears after 48 hours of admission. Areas of consolidation in unilateral or bilateral lung fields may be seen depending on severity. 

Left ventricular failure is an important differential diagnosis for ARDS. However, the patient's history of acute pancreatitis makes the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The patient's chest radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows left-sided pneumothorax with the partial collapse of the left lung. Best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is PA view in full expiration.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of a pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax in a patient with bilateral pneumonia. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’).

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

Image: Myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing

(A) Normal muscle

(B) - McArdle's disease

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Symptoms

GSD type 0

Glycogen synthase

Hypoglycemia

Early death

GSD type Ia

Von Gierke's disease

Glucose-6- phosphatase

Hepatomegaly and renomegaly due to glycogen accumulation

Severe fasting hypoglycemia

Growth failure

Lactic acidosis

Hyperuricemia

Hyperlipidemia

GSD type Ib

Endoplasmic reticulum glucose-6- phosphate transporter

Same as Von Gierke's disease

Recurrent infections due to impaired neutrophil function

GSD type II

Pompe's disease

Lysosomal α1,4:1,6 glucosidase

(Acid maltase)

Muscle weakness

Death by age ~2 years (infantile variant)

Cardiomegaly and heart failure

GSD type III

Cori's/Forbe's disease

(Limit dextrinosis)

Glycogen debranching enzyme

Muscle weakness

Fasting hypoglycemia

Hepatomegaly due to accumulation of branched chain polysaccharide (limit dextrins)

Growth retardation

GSD type IV

Andersen disease

Glycogen branching enzyme

Failure to thrive

Hepatomegaly due to accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points

Death at age ~5 years

GSD type V

McArdle disease

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

Exercise-induced cramps

Renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria

Second wind phenomenon

GSD type VI

Her's disease

Liver glycogen phosphorylase

Generally benign

Mild hypoglycemia

Hepatomegaly

GSD type VII

Tarui's disease

Muscle phosphofructokinase

Exercise-induced muscle cramps and weakness

Growth retardation

Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain in the forearm after falling down the stairs. The plain radiograph is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of Colles’ fracture.

The radiograph shows a transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist. The fracture appears extra-articular. In the AP view, the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated. This is characteristic of Colles' fracture.  

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Complications:

  • Stiffness of joints: Finger stiffness is commonly seen
  • Malunion - can produce dinner-fork deformity
  • Subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome - Uncommon
  • Sudek's osteodystrophy - Colles' fracture is the commonest cause of this condition in the upper limb.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.
